newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS - Tech stocks plunge on earnings warnings.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Tech stocks plunge on earnings warnings.

text.p: Technology stocks tumbled Tuesday after two more high-tech companies issued warnings about earnings, sparking fears of a broad slowdown in the personal computer industry.
"There is some concern in general about the health of the PC industry and it's just started to show up ... and more and more people are getting concerned," Gruntal & Co. analyst David Takata said.

The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index lost 19.88 points to 1,384.91, led by heavy volume in Intel Corp, which warned on Friday that second-quarter earnings would not meet expectations on Wall Street, largely because of weakness in Europe.

Two more warnings after the market closed on Monday unnerved the market. Seagate Technology Inc, a maker of disk drives, and Cabletron Systems Inc, a maker of computer network equipment, both said their earnings may be weaker than expected.

Cabletron's stock lost a third of its value Tuesday, falling $15.50 to $30.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, where more than 25.8 million shares changed hands in consolidated trading, making it the most active issue and the biggest loser of the session.
Seagate lost $3.625 to $38.75, also on the NYSE.

"It looks like there is some overall slowdown and whatever it is, it's magnified in Europe," said David Wu of ABN/Amro. "If it was just a product transition, why should Europe be the weakest? They are always the last to move to new products."
Ashok Kumar at Southcoast Capital Corp. said the retreat from the sector was probably temporary, noting the stocks have had a strong run in recent weeks.

"It just was a confluence of all the factors. To begin with, it is a traditionally weak season and (tech stocks) have had a good run of it. The safest thing to do is to step back and wait for the dust to settle," Kumar said.

The two men hardest hit by the sell-off were Cabletron Chairman Craig Benson and Chief Executive Robert Levine, the company's co-founders, who jointly own 25 percent of its stock. The drop cost them each about $250 million in share value.
The sell-off quickly spread across the high-tech sector. Even companies that have said sales and profits look good -- such as Compaq Computer Corp. -- took a beating.
Compaq tumbled $7.625 to $100, Dell Computer Corp shed $5.25 to $108.125, Microsoft Corp. lost $3.625 to $120.75 on Nasdaq and International Business Machines Corp fell $2.75 to $84.375.

The warnings fueled fears the PC market may be slowing, particularly overseas. But Compaq, the world's largest personal computer maker, said last week it had a strong April and May and demand in Europe was robust.
Seagate Chairman Al Shugard said in an interview on Monday that he saw no weakness in PCs and that demand still was outstripping supply for PC disk drives.

David Kirkpatrick, Cabletron's chief financial officer, said in an interview Tuesday that concerns over the upcoming quarter were linked to Europe. "We tend to typify our summer quarter as slowest, especially for Europe," he said. "Coming off a short quarter, we are especially cautious."
Asked if the problems were industrywide or specific to Cabletron, Kirkpatrick said he could not say.
European economies are generally not as strong as the U.S. economy, and many countries are tightening their belts to qualify for the planned single European currency.
For its part, Intel officials told analysts Tuesday it was too early to say if the weakness in European sales would translate to a broader industry slowdown, analysts said.
Andrew Neff at Bear Stearns & Co. said much of Tuesday's drop was just jitters among high-tech investors. "It's broad technology weakness," he said.
